In “Friday the 13th Part VI: Jason Lives” (1986), Jason Voorhees emerges from his own grave.']]), ('Ahh, but the moon was full
 And you had a chance
 To be all alone
 But you’re not alone', [['A typical horror movie trope is a pair of lovers being alone at night (often with a full moon illuminating the space,) then cue the villain.']])]

annotation:
[('Freedom, we’re gonna ring the bell
 Freedom to rock, freedom to talk
 Freedom, raise your fist and yell
 Freedom to rock, freedom to talk
 Freedom-ring', [['This patriotic verse displays how patriotism in America (the honoring of our Founding Fathers and their moral humanity) relies not upon doing what government tells us, but in thinking for ourselves and embracing our human rights, even if they are threatened by authority figures.']]), ('Back off preacher, I don’t care if it’s Sunday', [['This line demonstrates the corporatism that has taken over religion, while having cryptic intentions. Government also commonly uses religion to justify their actions, saying “In God We Trust.” and “One Nation Under God” while continuing to impose their own intentions on the public. Religion has been used and corrupted as a means to justify greed on a level the public is able to connect to. They don’t let the public worship how they want, but rather tell them when to pray, controlling them rather than allowing them to serve God and humanity.']]), ('You’re playing God from your ivory tower', [['The privileged corporation owners and and politicians make deals behind the public’s back, meanwhile expecting us to execute their every command as if it were the will of God. They stay secluded from the society they created, apart from the harsh reality of poverty, crime, and the enslavement of daily life, while expecting us to fight their wars and pay their taxes without any say over where that goes. We are cogs in their machine, allowing us to produce so they will reap the benefits.']]), ('Freedom, we’re gonna ring the bell
 Freedom to rock, freedom to talk
 Freedom, raise your fist and yell
 Freedom to rock, freedom to talk
 Freedom-ring', [['This patriotic verse displays how patriotism in America (the honoring of our Founding Fathers and their moral humanity) relies not upon doing what government tells us, but in thinking for ourselves and embracing our human rights, even if they are threatened by authority figures.']]), ('You’re such a saint, that ain’t the way we see you', [['Despite the fact that government wants us to worship their every move, they can’t help but let their actions and true intentions occasionally seep through to the public, causing us to question their authority, and our true ability to make change within the system.']]), ('Stop pretending that you’ve never been bad', [['This abrupt transition into the harsh criticism of the American government discredits the patriotic and proud nobility demonstrated in the song’s opening.

The Narrator demands the government expose itself for what it really is, and acknowledge the bad it has caused, rather than choose to only focus on the bad caused by other nations and paint America only as the hero. Every nation wants to paint themselves in a positive light for their citizens, no matter how much harm they have caused. The narrator asks the government to learn from its past, rather than deny it.']]), ('We the people of the United States
 In order to form a more perfect union', [['The first two lines of the preamble to the U.S. Constitution. Opening the song with this statement demonstrates the nobility of our Founding Father’s intentions and their vision for our nation. That which would later be corrupted as they wouldn’t live on to see America’s future.']])]

annotation: [('’Cause you’re gone without a trace\n In a sea of faceless imitators', [['The imitators are groupies. Groupies can offer company when a musician is away from home, but it’s an ultimately hollow experience. It won’t kill the pain of the narrator’s loneliness.']]), ('Starving at a feast\n And all this wine I’ve never tasted', [['As a rock star, the narrator has hundreds of women swarming him, but he’s stayed away before because he was in a relationship. Now that he’s been through a break-up, he can indulge. But does he want to?']])]

annotation:
[('Blow some steam
 C’mon and scream', [['“Blowing steam” is an expression for doing anything to calm oneself down. Screaming is often seen as a quick, effective, healthy, and cheap way to do this.']]), ('This ain’t your daddy talkin’
 You know, I know
 Your story ain’t so shocking
 You know, I know', [['At this point in the song, Cooper is joined by heavy metal pal Ozzy Osbourne, another musician known for his drug-filled and controversial past.



Both Cooper and Osbourne have been through the wringer, especially in regards to substance abuse. They seem to be acknowledging that their PSA of a song is more credible than a middle-aged man who has never seen a non-prescription drug in his life.

They also are telling the listener that, even though they feel that their life story is tragic, it really isn’t– especially when compared to Cooper & Osbourne’s lives.']]), ('Now I know you’ve been seeing red', [['When a bull sees red, they become agitated. In this sense, whatever is bumming the listener out makes them see red.']]), ('You stick a needle in your arm
 You bite the dust, you buy the farm', [['Using an indirect reference to heroin (which is injected), Cooper says that if the listener uses it, they’ll die. Biting the dust and buying the farm are both figures of speech for when someone passes away.

Buying the farm is believed to have caught on in popularity when the U.S. Government was training inexperienced pilots/crewmembers during World War II. Often, accidents in rural areas would lead to barns or fields being damaged. The Government would compensate the property owners with a check to repay for the damages, in a sense “buying the farm.”']])]

title: Feed My Frankenstein
lyrics:
Feed My Frankenstein Lyrics[Intro]
Yes, yes, I know you're hungry

I'm just good lookin'

And then I'm gonna eat ya

Right on time
Run my greasy fingers
Up your greasy spine

You don't want to talk

Like my flesh on the bone
Alive and lickin' on your
Ice cream cone

(He's a psycho)
Feed my Frankenstein

And it's feeding time

Feed my Frankenstein
Whoa whoa, baby chow down

He's a psycho

Meet my libido
(He's a psycho)

[Bridge + Chorus +Bridge]1Embed
annotation:
[('Feed my Frankenstein)', [['If reversed, the lyric sounds like ‘Hear our saviour. Hungry.’

Play from about 4:27 to hear it.
https://youtu.be/H1-Ys3WpVyk']]), ('Well, I ain’t no veggie
 Like my flesh on the bone
 Alive and lickin’ on your
 Ice cream cone', [['Here Alice Cooper describes the “mutual consumption” occurring between the “lovers”. By not being a veggie, Alice Cooper is implying that he is providing meat for his lover, vis-a-vis his penis. Simultaneously he is engaged in the “consumption” of his partner’s genitalia. This is commonly referred to as the “69” sexual position.']]), ('Velcro candy, sticky sweet', [['Velcro candy is an analogy for the female genitalia, and their stickiness is describing their arousal.']]), ('And let me drink the wine
 From your fur tea cup', [['Here Alice Cooper is expressing to consume the vaginal juices secreted by his desired copulation partner.']]), ('Feed my Frankenstein
 Meet my libido
 (He’s a psycho)
 Feed my Frankenstein
 Hungry for love
 And it’s feeding time', [['Here Alice Cooper explicitly refers to his libido as being analogous to Frankenstein’s monster. “Frankenstein” could imply the phallic imagery of a “beef frank”, but it also implies the unregulatable horror of a monster that is out of his control and is in desperate need.']]), ('I’m a hungry man
 But I don’t want pizza
 I’ll blow down your house
 And then I’m gonna eat ya', [['Here, Alice Cooper is expressing his monstrous desire for copulation. Here “blow down your house” refers to the story of the “3 Little Pigs” where the “Big Bad Wolf” destroys the protective domicile of the titular pigs. Whereas in the “3 Little Pigs”, the wolf wants to consume the pigs for a meal, here Alice Cooper is implying he wants to perform cunnilingus.']]), ('Yes, yes, I know you’re hungry
 And here comes dinner', [['In this sketch-like opening to the song, Alice Cooper is acting as Dr. Frankenstein talking to his “monster” that dinner is arriving.

In this song, Frankenstein’s monster is Alice Cooper’s sex drive (libido), and the “dinner” would be a potential copulation source.']])]

title: Hurricane Years
lyrics:

Got no respect for the law

It's the cutting edge of the saw

Sometimes I break down and cry

To burn away my sins

On the side of the road

I know I'm way too young to die

Oh, I got a ticket to to nowhere
Got no respect for the law
I got no use 'cause it's all abuse
It's the business end of the saw

In the hurricane years
We're living in the hurricane years
Oh, in the hurricane years
We're blowing in the hurricane yearsEmbed

title: Goin' To The River
lyrics:
Summertime Lyrics[Verse 1: Hayden Forbes]
(School's out!)
Alice Cooper
Cool now?
No, it's June wow
Time to go and let the sun shine right in
And keep up with the temp while I’m rhymin'
You never seen somethin' like this
A fresh start for the bright night lights bliss
Sunbathe in the sand lookin' lifeless
And party 24/7 till the ice hits
Grab your towels!
(Time to hit the, time to hit the)
Time to hit the seaside
Or maybe to the cabin
Pure remedies when it’s beach time
Can’t you see I’m hittin' could nine?
Winter me says it’s about time
Can’t believe all the sunny days that I’m seein'
So many options where do we begin?
[Chorus: Melina Grace]
When it all cools down the fall
That's when we look back at it all
Sunshine’s when the fun gets goin'
Oh you know it, oh you know it
Winter comes, it’s cold and icy
Spring comes ‘round and it warms up nicely
But now we’re out, the sun will shine
Don’t you know that it’s summertime

[Bridge: Melina Grace, Hayden Forbes, & Both]
Party time like it’s the summer of
‘17
Bike rides and breezy adventures
It better be
UV’s stoppin' the frost
The sun's glistening
This summer’s number one
Hey, are you listening?!

[Verse 2: Hayden Forbes]
It’s July now and I’m relaxin' back
And it’s a fact that I don’t have to pass a class
And this rap will be scripted as an adlib that’s
Impeccable, incredible, and that’s a fact
Stress-free, no testing
So don’t test me and I’m guessing
A couple of shots, a few drinks on the rocks
Sunshines, fun times, dive in from the docks
Now this heatwave has got the A/C ablastin’
For this super fun summer that’s why I’m rappin’
Feet tappin' for the beach balls, snow cones, and sunblock
River tubes, flip flops, free days, and whatnot
You might also like[Chorus: Melina Grace]
When it all cools down the fall
That's when we look back at it all
Sunshine’s when the fun gets goin'
Oh you know it, oh you know it
Winter comes, it’s cold and icy
Spring comes ‘round and it warms up nicely
But now we’re out, the sun will shine
Don’t you know that it’s summertime

[Verse 3: Hayden Forbes]
Don’t want this August to end now
And I’m honest so you know I won’t pretend now
Can’t stand the thought of goin' back to the place
Where I’m baggin' books
Homework, gross lunch, and mean glares are the classic looks
And daydreamin' of the days where the heat bears down on your forehead
Sunglasses, tank tops, swim trunks, friends, and fun times
That’s what I’m all for and
Val, Liz, Collin, Alex, Tabi, keep soarin’!
Veronica, Clay, Play Casts, and Jordan
When it comes to the peeps to shout out
You know I know there’s more and
Even Helen and Brady I’m adorin’!
(Don’t ignore it!)
For the rest of the year when we’re trapped all-day
Keep in mind once school’s out, then it’s anchors aweigh
Go and set sail from rivers and lakes
Tubes a floatin’
Till next time when I see you all then
[Chorus: Melina Grace]
When it all cools down the fall
That's when we look back at it all
Sunshine’s when the fun gets goin'
Oh you know it, oh you know it
Winter comes, it’s cold and icy
Spring comes ‘round and it warms up nicely
But now we’re out, the sun will shine
Don’t you know that it’s summertime
When it all cools down the fall
That's when we look back at it all
Sunshine’s when the fun gets goin'
Oh you know it, oh you know it
Winter comes, it’s cold and icy
Spring comes ‘round and it warms up nicely
But now we’re out, the sun will shine
Don’t you know that it’s summertimeEmbed
annotation:
[('Keep in mind once school’s out, then it’s anchors aweigh', [['I was in a play in a really weird play called Anchor’s Aweigh, and it’s not the one with Frank Sinatra.

I had to reference it after naming the Play Casts']]), ('Hey, are you listening?!', [['Are you?!']]), ('Or maybe to the cabin', [['One of my cousins was originally going to sing the chorus. The song started with her in mind because she said she wanted to make a song with me. Our family has a tiny little cabin up north we go to every summer, I had to reference it.

Unfortunately, she couldn’t sing it by the time I wrote the part so Melina stepped in, which helped me write the bridge!']]), ('Party time like it’s the summer of
 ‘17
 Bike rides and breezy adventures
 It better be', [['This will forever be the best summer of my life, Melina and I hung out almost every day. Bike rides are Richland Center all the time

Ahh the good old days…']]), ('It’s July now and I’m relaxin’ back
 And it’s a fact that I don’t have to pass a class
 And this rap will be scripted as an adlib that’s
 Impeccable, incredible, and that’s a fact', [['Sometimes I can freestyle, here’s one of my most notable examples']])]

Hey blood brother
Hey, hey, hey
Hey blood brother
Hey blood brother
Hey blood brother
Hey, hey, hey

Bag of bones

You're alone, bro!
You're all aloneEmbed
annotation: [('And a road map on my arm', [['Habitual drug users who inject substances will often display highly visible blue veins around the injection site resembling the lines of a road map.']]), ('I got a pocket full of rocks', [['“Rock” is a common slang term for crack cocaine, often sold in jagged nuggets.']])]

annotation:
[('Blow some steam
 C’mon and scream', [['“Blowing steam” is an expression for doing anything to calm oneself down. Screaming is often seen as a quick, effective, healthy, and cheap way to do this.']]), ('This ain’t your daddy talkin’
 You know, I know
 Your story ain’t so shocking
 You know, I know', [['At this point in the song, Cooper is joined by heavy metal pal Ozzy Osbourne, another musician known for his drug-filled and controversial past.



Both Cooper and Osbourne have been through the wringer, especially in regards to substance abuse. They seem to be acknowledging that their PSA of a song is more credible than a middle-aged man who has never seen a non-prescription drug in his life.

They also are telling the listener that, even though they feel that their life story is tragic, it really isn’t– especially when compared to Cooper & Osbourne’s lives.']]), ('Now I know you’ve been seeing red', [['When a bull sees red, they become agitated. In this sense, whatever is bumming the listener out makes them see red.']]), ('You stick a needle in your arm
 You bite the dust, you buy the farm', [['Using an indirect reference to heroin (which is injected), Cooper says that if the listener uses it, they’ll die. Biting the dust and buying the farm are both figures of speech for when someone passes away.

Buying the farm is believed to have caught on in popularity when the U.S. Government was training inexperienced pilots/crewmembers during World War II. Often, accidents in rural areas would lead to barns or fields being damaged. The Government would compensate the property owners with a check to repay for the damages, in a sense “buying the farm.”']])]

title: Feed My Frankenstein
lyrics:

And here comes dinner

Right on time
Run my greasy fingers
Up your greasy spine
[Chorus]
Feed my Frankenstein

(He's a psycho)
Feed my Frankenstein
Hungry for love
And it's feeding time

[Verse 2]
You don't want to talk
So baby, shut up
And let me drink the wine
From your fur tea cup
Velcro candy, sticky sweet
Make my tattoos
Melt in the heat
Well, I ain't no veggie
Like my flesh on the bone
Alive and lickin' on your
Ice cream cone

[Chorus]
Feed my Frankenstein
Meet my libido
(He's a psycho)
Feed my Frankenstein
Hungry for love
And it's feeding time
You might also like[Bridge]
Baby whoa whoa, oh yeah
Feed my Frankenstein
Whoa whoa, baby chow down
Feed my Frankenstein

He's a psycho

Feed my Frankenstein
Meet my libido
(He's a psycho)

[Bridge + Chorus +Bridge]1Embed
annotation:
[('Feed my Frankenstein)', [['If reversed, the lyric sounds like ‘Hear our saviour. Hungry.’

Play from about 4:27 to hear it.
https://youtu.be/H1-Ys3WpVyk']]), ('Well, I ain’t no veggie
 Like my flesh on the bone
 Alive and lickin’ on your
 Ice cream cone', [['Here Alice Cooper describes the “mutual consumption” occurring between the “lovers”. By not being a veggie, Alice Cooper is implying that he is providing meat for his lover, vis-a-vis his penis. Simultaneously he is engaged in the “consumption” of his partner’s genitalia. This is commonly referred to as the “69” sexual position.']]), ('Velcro candy, sticky sweet', [['Velcro candy is an analogy for the female genitalia, and their stickiness is describing their arousal.']]), ('And let me drink the wine
 From your fur tea cup', [['Here Alice Cooper is expressing to consume the vaginal juices secreted by his desired copulation partner.']]), ('Feed my Frankenstein
 Meet my libido
 (He’s a psycho)
 Feed my Frankenstein
 Hungry for love
 And it’s feeding time', [['Here Alice Cooper explicitly refers to his libido as being analogous to Frankenstein’s monster. “Frankenstein” could imply the phallic imagery of a “beef frank”, but it also implies the unregulatable horror of a monster that is out of his control and is in desperate need.']]), ('I’m a hungry man
 But I don’t want pizza
 I’ll blow down your house
 And then I’m gonna eat ya', [['Here, Alice Cooper is expressing his monstrous desire for copulation. Here “blow down your house” refers to the story of the “3 Little Pigs” where the “Big Bad Wolf” destroys the protective domicile of the titular pigs. Whereas in the “3 Little Pigs”, the wolf wants to consume the pigs for a meal, here Alice Cooper is implying he wants to perform cunnilingus.']]), ('Yes, yes, I know you’re hungry
 And here comes dinner', [['In this sketch-like opening to the song, Alice Cooper is acting as Dr. Frankenstein talking to his “monster” that dinner is arriving.

In this song, Frankenstein’s monster is Alice Cooper’s sex drive (libido), and the “dinner” would be a potential copulation source.']])]

title: House of Fire
lyrics:
House of Fire Lyrics[Intro]

annotation:
[('I’m in the middle without any plans
 I’m a boy and I’m a man', [['He’s in the middle- neither young nor old. Neither an adult nor a child. Or perhaps both of those things.']]), ('I got a baby’s brain and an old man’s heart', [['A baby’s brain, because he is still irresponsible, but an old man’s heart, because he lived as much difficulties (heartbreaks?) as old people']]), ('I’m eighteen', [['Bob Erzin, the man who helped make this song a hit originally misheard the lyrics as “I’m edgy!”, bothering the band members tremendously. Perhaps this was because Alice Cooper was 23 when he recorded the song.']]), ('[Verse 1]', [['Originally this song was 8 minutes long and was played live in tandem with a psychedelic reel of gory pictures. Unofficial 6th member of the band Bob Erzin helped them trim it down to a neat 2:56 seconds.']]), ('Eighteen, eighteen and I like it', [['Johnny Rotten sang this song when he auditioned for Sex Pistols.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8MN2uhTo-rQ']]), ('Eighteen, I just don’t know what I want
 Eighteen, I gotta get away
 I gotta get out of this place, I’ll go runnin in outer space, oh yeah', [['It addresses the inner conflicts of a typical teenager who becomes an adult once he reaches 18. There is confusion about his life goal and what he wants to achieve as a man. He enjoys the newly gained freedoms of adulthood, but has no clues on what to do. He doesn’t want to face reality, such that he wants to escape from the real world. The Alice Cooper group wrote this song during the Vietnam war and eighteen was the age that was old enough to be enrolled but not old enough to vote. There is the American dream deep in his heart, to have freedom of choosing what he does instead of being in the army, and of expressing his own opinions to society.']])]

annotation:
[('Sleepin’ don’t come very easy
 In a straight white vest', [['Indeed, sleeping can be very difficult in a straitjacket!

During concert performances of ‘Ballad Of Dwight Fry,’ Cooper often wears a red or white straitjacket as a nurse (often played by his wife) harasses and taunts him, pictured below.']]), ('I grabbed my hat and I got my coat
 And I, I ran into the street', [['Through some unspecified way, the character is now escaping the mental asylum with apparent ease, but still in a hurry.']]), ('I was gone for all those days
 But I, was not all alone
 I made friends with a lot of people
 In the danger zone', [['What Fry is saying is that he had other patients with him that were also mentally ill, and that he became friends with them. These patients were in the danger zone, so they must be mentally ill, just like him.']]), ('Held up in the intensive care ward
 Lyin’ on the floor', [['This verse contrasts with the previous one, since Fry was promoting an idea that things weren’t as bad as they could’ve been, but then he reveals that he was being held in the intensive care ward, where the most acute cases are directed to, revealing that Fry’s illness is out of control.

The fact that Fry was lying on the floor implies that he could be either depressed or drugged, reforcing the idea that things were bad, very bad.']]), ('I was gone for fourteen days
 I could’ve been gone for more', [['Fry could have been in the psychiatric ward for more than fourteen days due to many reasons, all related to his illness, like aggressive or psychotic behaviors.

Therefore, what Fry is trying to say is that the situation is not that bad – it could’ve been worse, like if he had to stay for more than fourteen days at the intensive care ward.

Maybe this is a subtle form of expressing how Fry wants to fix everything and convince people that hope should remain preserved and that things will be better soon.

These verses are expressing the desperate wish of wanting his life back.']]), ('He’s been gone for so long
 Do you think he’ll ever come home?', [['The Child is worried about her father, asking if he’s ever coming home (getting better). Also, the child is often associated with purity and innocence, and as Fry’s daughter becomes more and more worried, she starts to understand the situation as a whole and loses her hope of seeing her father again – a sad scenario for a child to be inserted.']]), ('Mommy, where’s daddy?', [['The question of the child represents how Fry’s illness affected everybody around him, the child is Fry’s son and stands for his family, so the main idea of this passage is how bad the situation is, since it’s affecting Fry’s family.']])]

annotation:
[('Dead babies, can’t take care of themselves', [['Based on how you hear it, this line can be heard in one of two ways:

Dead babies can’t take care of themselves

…Or…

Dead babies can take care of themselves

Alice Cooper’s official Twitter account once used the first variant. However, it is very likely that this post was made by a social media manager. Meanwhile, a review by Rolling Stone goes with the second variant.

The first variant is fairly straightforward, blunt, and grim. Arguably, the second variant is even darker, sounding almost like something a spiteful parent would say, reinforcing the song’s themes of neglect. Regardless of what you hear, it seems the line is meant to have ambiguity.']])]

annotation:
[('Kids want a savior, they don’t need a fake
 I wanna be elected', [['With this line, the cocky politician narrator compares himself to the Christian god whose only son, Jesus, is viewed as a savior.

Additionally, he appears to be hinting that other gods including the Christian one and his son are fakes, implying that he is the real god.']]), ('Good evening Mr. & Mrs. America
 And all ships at sea', [['Walter Winchell was a famous radio news reporter who died (of old age) just before “Elected” came out.  Winchell would usually open his broadcasts by saying some variant of, “Good evening, Mr. and Mrs. America from border to border and coast to coast and all the ships at sea. Let’s go to press.”
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0RS3MsxWFWY']]), ('I’m your yankee doodle dandy in a gold Rolls Royce', [['“Yankee Doodle” is a famously goofy patriotic song The song includes the line “Yankee Doodle dandy”, which was all the inspiration Hollywood needed for this 1942 patriotic musical:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=StDpLge_ITM

A “dandy” is a fancy man, so having a luxury car would fit the part.  A Rolls Royce, though, is over the top, especially since “Yankee Doodle” is about how Americans are different from the British, and Rolls Royce is famously British.']]), ('I’m top prime cut of meat, I’m your choice', [['Voters often describe the candidate that they’re voting for as their “choice” for office.



Alice notices that elections are a bit like a meat market.  In the USA, “prime” and “choice” are the government’s official designations for the best cuts of beef.



So Alice’s campaign platform is to admit that politics is just another meat market – but at least he’s the candidate who’s letting you in on it.']])]

title: Go to Hell
lyrics:
Go to Hell Lyrics[Intro]
For criminal acts and violence on the stage
For being a brat refusing to act your age
For all of the decent citizens you've enraged
You can go to Hell

[Verse 1]
For gambling and drinking alcohol constantly
For making us doubt our parent's authority
For choosing to be a living obscenity
You can go to Hell
[Hook]
You're something that never should have happened
You'd even make your Grandma sick

[Verse 2]
You'd poison a blind man's dog and steal his cane
You'd gift wrap a leper and mail him to your Aunt Jane
You'd even force-feed a diabetic a candy cane
You can go to Hell

[Instrumental break]

[Hook]
You're something that never should have happened
You'd even make your Grandma sick

[Outro]
For criminal acts and violence on the stage
For being a brat refusing to act your age
For all of the decent citizens you've enraged
You can go to Hell

[Instrumental outro]You might also likeEmbed
annotation: [('For making us doubt our parent’s authority', [['Alice is well known as being the king of shock-rock, which was a large part of American teenager counter-culture in the 1970s. The lifestyle around said teenagers generally included a disdain for their own parents and their authority over them as individuals.']]), ('Drinking alcohol constantly', [['From the 1970s up to 1984, Alice Cooper had an addiction to alcohol, of which he is now open about in interviews. After being hospitalized more than once for alcoholism and dropped from his record label, he got sober.']]), ('For all of the decent citizens you’ve enraged', [['One such ‘decent citizen’ Alice Cooper had enraged was none other than Ann Landers with his 1973 track, ‘Cold Ethyl’.']]), ('For all of the decent citizens you’ve enraged', [['One such ‘decent citizen’ Alice Cooper had enraged was none other than Ann Landers with his 1973 track, ‘Cold Ethyl’.']]), ('For criminal acts and violence on the stage', [['By 1976, Cooper’s stage shows had already involved hangings, guillotine executions, and grotesque stage props.']])]

annotation: [('I love Detroit ’cause I was born to fight', [['Detroit is the hometown of Alice Cooper, who was born Vincent Furnier in the Motor City on February 4, 1948']]), ('I love the Tigers but I hate the Mets', [['When considering that “Loving the Tigers” (like Detroit native Cooper does in real life) while simultaneously “Hating the Mets” is an odd concept since the American League Tigers and National League Mets never faced each other in a World Series and would not face each other until Interleague play started in 1997, it becomes apparent that Cooper wrote the line in order to complete a rhyme.']]), ('Homemade pie', [['Pie was brought to America by the first English settlers in the 17th century. Also, there is a saying of being “as American as apple pie” dating back to the 1900s.']]), ('I love Old Glory', [["‘Old Glory’ is the nickname of the United States' flag."]]), ('I love my chicken Kentucky Fried...\n Finger Lickin’ Good!', [['A little shout-out to one of America’s most notable fast-food chains, Kentucky Fried Chicken, or KFC.']]), ('I think them Ruskies should be sterilized', [['An offensive slur for native-born Russians. In this song, Cooper advocates for making it so that Russians not be able to reproduce.']]), ('I love that mountain with those four big heads', [['Referring to Mount Rushmore, located in South Dakota’s Black Hills National Forest. From left to right, it depicts George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Theodore Roosevelt, and Abraham Lincoln.']])]

FreedomYou might also likeEmbed
annotation:
[('Freedom, we’re gonna ring the bell
 Freedom to rock, freedom to talk
 Freedom, raise your fist and yell
 Freedom to rock, freedom to talk
 Freedom-ring', [['This patriotic verse displays how patriotism in America (the honoring of our Founding Fathers and their moral humanity) relies not upon doing what government tells us, but in thinking for ourselves and embracing our human rights, even if they are threatened by authority figures.']]), ('Back off preacher, I don’t care if it’s Sunday', [['This line demonstrates the corporatism that has taken over religion, while having cryptic intentions. Government also commonly uses religion to justify their actions, saying “In God We Trust.” and “One Nation Under God” while continuing to impose their own intentions on the public. Religion has been used and corrupted as a means to justify greed on a level the public is able to connect to. They don’t let the public worship how they want, but rather tell them when to pray, controlling them rather than allowing them to serve God and humanity.']]), ('You’re playing God from your ivory tower', [['The privileged corporation owners and and politicians make deals behind the public’s back, meanwhile expecting us to execute their every command as if it were the will of God. They stay secluded from the society they created, apart from the harsh reality of poverty, crime, and the enslavement of daily life, while expecting us to fight their wars and pay their taxes without any say over where that goes. We are cogs in their machine, allowing us to produce so they will reap the benefits.']]), ('Freedom, we’re gonna ring the bell
 Freedom to rock, freedom to talk
 Freedom, raise your fist and yell
 Freedom to rock, freedom to talk
 Freedom-ring', [['This patriotic verse displays how patriotism in America (the honoring of our Founding Fathers and their moral humanity) relies not upon doing what government tells us, but in thinking for ourselves and embracing our human rights, even if they are threatened by authority figures.']]), ('You’re such a saint, that ain’t the way we see you', [['Despite the fact that government wants us to worship their every move, they can’t help but let their actions and true intentions occasionally seep through to the public, causing us to question their authority, and our true ability to make change within the system.']]), ('Stop pretending that you’ve never been bad', [['This abrupt transition into the harsh criticism of the American government discredits the patriotic and proud nobility demonstrated in the song’s opening.

The Narrator demands the government expose itself for what it really is, and acknowledge the bad it has caused, rather than choose to only focus on the bad caused by other nations and paint America only as the hero. Every nation wants to paint themselves in a positive light for their citizens, no matter how much harm they have caused. The narrator asks the government to learn from its past, rather than deny it.']]), ('We the people of the United States
 In order to form a more perfect union', [['The first two lines of the preamble to the U.S. Constitution. Opening the song with this statement demonstrates the nobility of our Founding Father’s intentions and their vision for our nation. That which would later be corrupted as they wouldn’t live on to see America’s future.']])]

annotation:
[('Blow some steam
 C’mon and scream', [['“Blowing steam” is an expression for doing anything to calm oneself down. Screaming is often seen as a quick, effective, healthy, and cheap way to do this.']]), ('This ain’t your daddy talkin’
 You know, I know
 Your story ain’t so shocking
 You know, I know', [['At this point in the song, Cooper is joined by heavy metal pal Ozzy Osbourne, another musician known for his drug-filled and controversial past.



Both Cooper and Osbourne have been through the wringer, especially in regards to substance abuse. They seem to be acknowledging that their PSA of a song is more credible than a middle-aged man who has never seen a non-prescription drug in his life.

They also are telling the listener that, even though they feel that their life story is tragic, it really isn’t– especially when compared to Cooper & Osbourne’s lives.']]), ('Now I know you’ve been seeing red', [['When a bull sees red, they become agitated. In this sense, whatever is bumming the listener out makes them see red.']]), ('You stick a needle in your arm
 You bite the dust, you buy the farm', [['Using an indirect reference to heroin (which is injected), Cooper says that if the listener uses it, they’ll die. Biting the dust and buying the farm are both figures of speech for when someone passes away.

Buying the farm is believed to have caught on in popularity when the U.S. Government was training inexperienced pilots/crewmembers during World War II. Often, accidents in rural areas would lead to barns or fields being damaged. The Government would compensate the property owners with a check to repay for the damages, in a sense “buying the farm.”']])]

annotation:
[('Feed my Frankenstein)', [['If reversed, the lyric sounds like ‘Hear our saviour. Hungry.’

Play from about 4:27 to hear it.
https://youtu.be/H1-Ys3WpVyk']]), ('Well, I ain’t no veggie
 Like my flesh on the bone
 Alive and lickin’ on your
 Ice cream cone', [['Here Alice Cooper describes the “mutual consumption” occurring between the “lovers”. By not being a veggie, Alice Cooper is implying that he is providing meat for his lover, vis-a-vis his penis. Simultaneously he is engaged in the “consumption” of his partner’s genitalia. This is commonly referred to as the “69” sexual position.']]), ('Velcro candy, sticky sweet', [['Velcro candy is an analogy for the female genitalia, and their stickiness is describing their arousal.']]), ('And let me drink the wine
 From your fur tea cup', [['Here Alice Cooper is expressing to consume the vaginal juices secreted by his desired copulation partner.']]), ('Feed my Frankenstein
 Meet my libido
 (He’s a psycho)
 Feed my Frankenstein
 Hungry for love
 And it’s feeding time', [['Here Alice Cooper explicitly refers to his libido as being analogous to Frankenstein’s monster. “Frankenstein” could imply the phallic imagery of a “beef frank”, but it also implies the unregulatable horror of a monster that is out of his control and is in desperate need.']]), ('I’m a hungry man
 But I don’t want pizza
 I’ll blow down your house
 And then I’m gonna eat ya', [['Here, Alice Cooper is expressing his monstrous desire for copulation. Here “blow down your house” refers to the story of the “3 Little Pigs” where the “Big Bad Wolf” destroys the protective domicile of the titular pigs. Whereas in the “3 Little Pigs”, the wolf wants to consume the pigs for a meal, here Alice Cooper is implying he wants to perform cunnilingus.']]), ('Yes, yes, I know you’re hungry
 And here comes dinner', [['In this sketch-like opening to the song, Alice Cooper is acting as Dr. Frankenstein talking to his “monster” that dinner is arriving.

In this song, Frankenstein’s monster is Alice Cooper’s sex drive (libido), and the “dinner” would be a potential copulation source.']])]

annotation:
[('Evergreen Terrace', [['The five-piece metalcore band are named after the street the Simpson family live on in American animated TV show of the same name.']]), ('The Stone Roses', [['The Stone Roses, a Mancunian rock band formed in 1983, got their name after guitarist John Squire seemingly spontaneously thought up the name. Speculation has arisen about whether the name was influenced by the Rolling Stones, or whether they had initially been called ‘English Rose’, but Ian Brown, the lead singer, denies this. In an interview, he says, “No, I don’t know where that English Rose story came from. John thought up the name ‘Stone Roses’ – something with a contrast, two words that went against each other”.']]), ('Zug Izland', [['This juggalo rock band was named after a private industrialized island in Detroit, which has now unfortunately closed down.

When asked about how the name came to be, lead singer Syn had this to say:

“It mainly came through the Dark Carnival… everything at Psychopathic Records seems to come from the Dark Carnival or through Violent J.”

In an article for Northern Express in 2007, Drummer 2 Phat had this to say:

“It is your first impression of Detroit when you pull in off of I-75 and look over the horizon and see this industrial island … Like the island, we see our band as toxic, dirty and raw.”

In yet another article in 2013, Producer Mike Puwal said this:

“The island of Zug is an actual island on the southwest side of Detroit.  It’s probably in the Guinness book of World Records as the dirtiest square mile on earth.  It seemed an appropriate name for clean cut fellows like us on the dirtiest label on Earth. Detroit was one of the greatest cities on earth, a long time ago.  Perhaps someday it can be again. ”']]), ('Dealey Plaza', [['A five piece deathcore band formed in 2012, from Fort Myers, Florida.']]), ('Dire Straits', [['The band took their name from the economic and political state Britain was in at the time of their formation (1977). To be in “dire straits” means to be in a position of trouble, as Britain was at the time.']]), ('Tomb Mold', [['In an interview with FULL METAL MEDIA, guitarist Derrick Vella confirmed that the band’s name is taken from Bloodborne, a popular action RPG developed by FromSoftware, best known as the creators of the Dark Souls games. In the game, there is an item called Tomb Mold that enables the player to create a Chalice Dungeon, which is essentially a labyrinthine challenge gauntlet filled with numerous enemies and bosses.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DWC3yuV1Uis&t=155s

This connection was also confirmed in another interview via Transcending Obscurity. When asked if there was any Bloodborne influence in the band name, Derrick responded:

Ha, definitely. I am an avid gamer but since Demon’s Souls I’ve played the hell out of every game Hidetaka Miyazaki has made. Bloodborne is probably my favourite out of the Souls-related games, especially from an atmosphere/design perspective. All the Lovecraft worship didn’t hurt it either.']]), ('L7', [['The band’s name is an alternate version of the slang term “square”, meaning an old-fashioned and uncool person. The term comes from the fact that it resembles a literal square. It was chosen deliberately by the band as a gender-neutral symbol.']]), ('Twist', [['The band’s name was inspired by a moment when Emma Fox’s dad called her a “twisted little fuck” when she was 13.']]), ('Sally', [['Inspired by the main protagonist of The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Sally Hardesty.']]), ('Crunt', [['Stu Spasm in an interview, when asked if the band’s name was meant to be ‘cunt’ with an added ‘r’:

NO. If you have ever been in a car crash or rear-ended another car, the sound you get is CRUNT. It’s like the sound of metal colliding. Then there is the sound of tinkling glass. We can’t get into any trouble with the riot grrrls, because we have a woman in the band. It’s not some kind of silly, purulent schoolboy thing.

Russell Simins has also described the band’s name as “the sound you get when you hit the snare drum really hard.”']])]

annotation:
[('Built idols out of mud', [['One of the Ten Commandments is to have no other gods before the one true God.']]), ('We took advice from that deceiving snake', [['The Bible opens with the story of Creation. As a TL;DR, Eve listens to the Devil (who took form as a serpent). He coaxed her into eating a fruit, which she shared with Adam.



It gave them knowledge God did not want them to have, and is often referred to as the original sin.']]), ('We’re spinning round on this ball of hate', [['Referencing the Earth.']])]

annotation: [('For making us doubt our parent’s authority', [['Alice is well known as being the king of shock-rock, which was a large part of American teenager counter-culture in the 1970s. The lifestyle around said teenagers generally included a disdain for their own parents and their authority over them as individuals.']]), ('Drinking alcohol constantly', [['From the 1970s up to 1984, Alice Cooper had an addiction to alcohol, of which he is now open about in interviews. After being hospitalized more than once for alcoholism and dropped from his record label, he got sober.']]), ('For all of the decent citizens you’ve enraged', [['One such ‘decent citizen’ Alice Cooper had enraged was none other than Ann Landers with his 1973 track, ‘Cold Ethyl’.']]), ('For all of the decent citizens you’ve enraged', [['One such ‘decent citizen’ Alice Cooper had enraged was none other than Ann Landers with his 1973 track, ‘Cold Ethyl’.']]), ('For criminal acts and violence on the stage', [['By 1976, Cooper’s stage shows had already involved hangings, guillotine executions, and grotesque stage props.']])]

annotation:
[('Sleepin’ don’t come very easy
 In a straight white vest', [['Indeed, sleeping can be very difficult in a straitjacket!

During concert performances of ‘Ballad Of Dwight Fry,’ Cooper often wears a red or white straitjacket as a nurse (often played by his wife) harasses and taunts him, pictured below.']]), ('I grabbed my hat and I got my coat
 And I, I ran into the street', [['Through some unspecified way, the character is now escaping the mental asylum with apparent ease, but still in a hurry.']]), ('I was gone for all those days
 But I, was not all alone
 I made friends with a lot of people
 In the danger zone', [['What Fry is saying is that he had other patients with him that were also mentally ill, and that he became friends with them. These patients were in the danger zone, so they must be mentally ill, just like him.']]), ('Held up in the intensive care ward
 Lyin’ on the floor', [['This verse contrasts with the previous one, since Fry was promoting an idea that things weren’t as bad as they could’ve been, but then he reveals that he was being held in the intensive care ward, where the most acute cases are directed to, revealing that Fry’s illness is out of control.

The fact that Fry was lying on the floor implies that he could be either depressed or drugged, reforcing the idea that things were bad, very bad.']]), ('I was gone for fourteen days
 I could’ve been gone for more', [['Fry could have been in the psychiatric ward for more than fourteen days due to many reasons, all related to his illness, like aggressive or psychotic behaviors.

Therefore, what Fry is trying to say is that the situation is not that bad – it could’ve been worse, like if he had to stay for more than fourteen days at the intensive care ward.

Maybe this is a subtle form of expressing how Fry wants to fix everything and convince people that hope should remain preserved and that things will be better soon.

These verses are expressing the desperate wish of wanting his life back.']]), ('He’s been gone for so long
 Do you think he’ll ever come home?', [['The Child is worried about her father, asking if he’s ever coming home (getting better). Also, the child is often associated with purity and innocence, and as Fry’s daughter becomes more and more worried, she starts to understand the situation as a whole and loses her hope of seeing her father again – a sad scenario for a child to be inserted.']]), ('Mommy, where’s daddy?', [['The question of the child represents how Fry’s illness affected everybody around him, the child is Fry’s son and stands for his family, so the main idea of this passage is how bad the situation is, since it’s affecting Fry’s family.']])]

annotation:
[('Built idols out of mud', [['One of the Ten Commandments is to have no other gods before the one true God.']]), ('We took advice from that deceiving snake', [['The Bible opens with the story of Creation. As a TL;DR, Eve listens to the Devil (who took form as a serpent). He coaxed her into eating a fruit, which she shared with Adam.



It gave them knowledge God did not want them to have, and is often referred to as the original sin.']]), ('We’re spinning round on this ball of hate', [['Referencing the Earth.']])]

annotation:
[('The Kid was in his crib, shady wore a bib
 And the posse wasn’t even alive', [['While funny, all of them are around the same age. At the time of this annotation, Kid Rock is 50, Eminem and Violent J are 48, and Shaggy 2 Dope is 46.

All of them were new borns or toddlers when Iggy, Ziggy, Alice, MC5, Ted Nugent, and Bob Seger were getting their starts.']]), ('Ted and Seger were burnin’ with fever
 And let the Silver bullets fly', [["Referring to Ted Nugent and Bob Seger. Both are proud rockers who hail from Detroit.

The part, “burnin' with the fever,” refers to Nugent’s hit, ‘Cat Scratch Fever.’

Bob Seger’s backing band was called the Siver Bullet Band."]]), ('Me and Iggy were giggin’ with Ziggy and kickin’ with the MC5', [['Right off the bat, Cooper name drops three major rock acts. Iggy refers to the former frontman of The Stooges, Iggy Pop. Ziggy was one of glam-rockstar David Bowie’s stage personas, Ziggy Stardust.

Bowie met Iggy in 1972 and even collaborated and produced albums with and for Iggy. After Iggy Pop checked himself into rehab for drug abuse, Bowie constantly visited him and even had Pop join him on his Station To Station tour.

MC5 is a Detroit-based band who had a major hit with the song ‘Kick Out The Jams.’']])]

annotation: [('Diamonds are forever', [['Possibly a nod to the early performances of ‘Halo of Flies,’ which included the alternate lyrics “Diamonds are forever.”\n\nPROPOSED SUGGESTION: It is likely referring to Diamonds Are Forever (1956) by Ian Fleming, as well as Diamonds Are Forever (1971). Alice Cooper was a fan of the Bond films, and even did The Man with the Golden Gun on Muscle of Love, which was meant for the film of the same name. It was not used because they had already contracted Lulu to do the song. Dirty Diamonds contains some Bond theme type elements to it.']])]

annotation:
[('We’ve been in this cell for 28 years, Steven
 We couldn’t have done all those horrible things', [['Steven is the main character from Alice Cooper’s debut solo album “Welcome to My Nightmare” and its sequel “Welcome 2 My Nightmare” (Cooper’s next album).  He also appeared as the main character in “The Last Temptation”, the song “Wind Up Toy” from “Hey Stoopid” and in the liner notes of “Alice Cooper Goes to Hell”.

Steven appears again in this album, mentioned in this song but the size of his role is up to the listener to decide.  Some fans believe that Steven is the Spider and that the Spider is talking to himself, while others believe that the Spider and Steven are just sharing the same cell and that the Spider is talking directly to Steven.  Either way, Steven appears on this album, his first appearance since “The Last Temptation” in 1994!']])]

annotation:
[('All I wanted, all I needed was someone to rescue me
 I was drowning, I was dying, now I’m free', [['Steven may be referring to the events of “Welcome to My Nightmare” here.  He may also have been talking about the events of “The Last Temptation”, saying he is now free from the Showman’s clutches.  He may also have been talking about being released from the mental hospital he was seen in on the song “Wind-Up Toy”.  And if Steven was also the serial killer “The Spider” on Alice Cooper’s previous album “Along Came a Spider” (supposedly he may have been sent to that hospital from “Wind-Up Toy” after the events of that album), he may be saying that he has a clean slate and rejected his murderous ways.']]), ('I was shattered, left in pieces And I felt so cold inside
 Then I called you from the darkness where I hide
 
 I am made of you
 I am made of you
 I am made of you
 I am made of you
 
 In the beginning you were revelation
 A river of salvation and now I believe', [['Whoever Steven (the main character from this album and also the original “Welcome to My Nightmare” album) is referring to is up to fans to decide.  He may be praying to God, or he could be singing in memory of Mercy (the girl from the album “The Last Temptation”, which also had Steven as the main character), who Steven says has given him hope.']])]

annotation:
[('But if I leave I could doze for hours
 And that will surely be the end of a coward like me', [['Cooper is acknowledging that it is ridiculous for a grown man to put off sleeping over his fear of nightmares.

However, he also seems to be saying that if he does go to sleep, he may die.']]), ('But if I leave I could doze for hours
 And that will surely be the end of a coward like me', [['Steven is acknowledging that it is ridiculous for a grown man to put off sleeping over his fear of nightmares.

However, he also seems to be saying that if he does go to sleep, he may die.']]), ('Caffeine! Caffeine!', [['After a cold shower, the song’s main character is engaged on drinking coffee in order to stay awake.']]), ('I’m shaking in the ice-cold shower', [['Taking a cold shower is commonly seen as a good way to wake up.']]), ('I gotta stay awake
 I just can’t sleep
 Because I know inside if I close my eyes
 It will be the death of me', [['A medical or psychological condition imposes that this song’s protagonist can’t sleep. Other possibility is that he has an assignment or work to accomplish during the late night.']]), ('A little speed is all I need', [['“Speed” is one of the most popular street names for amphetamine. This drug’s junkies used to be called “speed-freaks”, and one of the most notorious examples among musicians was Alice Cooper himself.']]), ('Amphetamine', [['Amphetamine is a drug that was very popular during the 70s. It stimulates the nervous system, just like caffeine. The song’s protagonist seemingly takes both to stay awake.']])]

annotation:
[('Scary’s on the wall
 Scary’s on his way', [['Since this song is about young children dealing drugs, this lyric is probably meant to symbolize that by using improper grammar, something a child who doesn’t have much speaking skills would say.']]), ('Bullets seek the place to bend you over', [['My interpretation is that “bullets” is just another word for “needles” and that the whole verse talks about needles constantly trying to bend you over or annihilate you, after every hit; in doing so, Jerry creates a metonymy because needles do not try to “bend you over”, heroin does.

PROPOSED SUGGESTION: Since Cantrell confirmed the song’s about gang violence, I think the lyric is more literal, as naturally, when someone experiences a great deal of pain, particularly from something like a bullet, it causes you to bend over in pain.']]), ('Take another hit
 And bury your brother', [['This could have multiple meanings. The first one being that someone takes a hit of drugs and overdosed or they are physically hit by a bullet or other deadly force.']]), ('Then you got hit
 And you should’ve known better', [['Hit, as in taking a hit of drugs, and also getting physically hurt through being hit or shot. “You Should’ve known better” is a phrase commonly used by parents scolding their children from things along the lines of drugs outlined in this song.']]), ('Another alley trip', [['Alleys are generally where drugs are dealed, and a trip to one would be to buy some.']])]

annotation:
[('When the sin lies bolder (Bolder)
 I’ll pluck out thine eye (I’ll pluck out thine eye)', [['This is a Biblical reference to the passage of Mathew 18:9 which reads:

Also, if your eye makes you stumble, tear it out and throw it away from you. It is better for you to enter one-eyed into life than to be thrown with two eyes into the fiery Ge·henʹna

Although this seems to be a sincere expression of guilt, when taken into context Jerry seems to be sarcastically mocking society’s moral standards, in particular those set out in the Bible.']]), ('My cup runneth over
 Like blood from a stone', [['The first line – my cup runneth over – is a reference to the Book of Psalms. It means that he has more than he needs, he is doing great.

The second line – like blood from a stone – means the exact opposite.

Jerry is telling us in sarcastic fashion that no, he’s not doing great. He’s also setting up the slew of religious metaphors to come in the song.']])]

annotation:
[('Feel the pain and keep it all in ’til you die
 Without eyes you cannot cry', [['“Feel the pain and keep it all in ‘til you die” could be referring to someone struggling with depression/pain, and they bottle it all inside of their brain until it becomes too much, or until they die.

Along with depression comes lack of emotion, or numbness. Its as if the person doesn’t even have eyes because they are unable to cry; they only wallow in their own misery without any form of outlet.']]), ('’Scuse the ’tude but I haven’t eaten today', [['Certain drugs can cause a loss of appetite, and lack of eating can cause a number of other problems; it can cause people to act agitated, cause headaches, and prolonged time without eating could result in fainting.']])]

 You know, I don’t need you

 Honey, I don’t need you
 I just can’t put you down
 Can’t put you down', [['Like in here he is describing the thoughts of using it and being hesitant of doing it again']]), ('[Chorus]', [['Most addicts struggle with the fact that so much subtance abuse can indeed kill them but they can’t put it down']]), ('[Verse 1]', [['The guitar and bass riff played during the intro and verse is very reminiscent of hair metal from the mid 1980s.

In fact, Alice In Chains themselves used to be known as “Alice N’ Chains” and played hair metal through the mid-late 1980s.

However by the turn of the decade, the overwhelming popularity of the “Seattle sound” along with drug abuse caused the band to shift to a more dark tone.

The riff played here is down tuned to d# (a half step down), adding a darker vibe to what would be a hair metal inspired riff.

By doing this, Alice In Chains pays respect to their roots while also adding a more eerie vibe to the verses of the song.']])]

annotation:
[('Now there’s time to give it all
 I put my fears behind again
 On skinned knees we’ll crawl', [['Playing on the first verse and somewhat contrary to it, now there is time to give it all, instead of not having it to give at all. This is the moment they should apply their efforts. The singer claims he has put his fears behind again – he could be scared of being close and intimate with someone (the indifference in the chorus), scared of trying to trust people after being cheated in the past, or just scared of trying and afraid of changes in general. The last verse has a loose meaning, albeit a hopeful one.']]), ('I wanna set you free, ah
 Yeah, recognize my disease, ah', [['The singer claims that he wants to set the other person free from his/her suffering, the suffering which he could’ve caused or brought upon them himself. This could mean a few things; ending the relationship or perhaps cessation of the abusive behavior. The second line may suggest the latter: “the disease” could refer to some sort of personality disorder or past trauma – oftentimes people who express abusive behaviors or hurt other people had been abused or hurt themselves and this type of behavior can be etched in their subconscious making them unaware of the harm they cause, or unaware of the possibility of behaving in an alternative way. Recognition is the first step towards seeking proper treatment, thus the plea.']]), ('I wanna set you free, ah
 Yeah, recognize my disease, ah', [['The singer claims that he wants to set the other person free from his/her suffering, the suffering which he could’ve caused or brought upon them himself. This could mean a few things; ending the relationship or perhaps cessation of the abusive behavior. The second line may suggest the latter: “the disease” could refer to some sort of personality disorder or past trauma – oftentimes people who express abusive behaviors or hurt other people had been abused or hurt themselves and this type of behavior can be etched in their subconscious making them unaware of the harm they cause, or unaware of the possibility of behaving in an alternative way. Recognition is the first step towards seeking proper treatment, thus the plea.']]), ('There’s no time to give at all
 I cause you grief and blow my hatred
 Further in your mind', [['The song begins with the singer’s claim that he is aware of the harm he’s been bringing upon the person he is in a relationship with. There is no time to give; something must be done about it hastily.']]), ('You reach, I run, you fall
 On skinned knees you crawl', [['One person is more attached than the other, trying to hold on to that person as he/she is pushing themselves away, running away so to speak. As a result, the one person feels pain from chasing for so long and falls onto their knees, but still continues regardless of the pain.']])]

annotation:
[('(I know something ’bout you, I know something ’bout you) I know something', [['The jeering nature of these lines can be interpreted as someone tauting him and holding his addiction above his head. This idea that drug addiction is a secret or something to be ashamed of is brought up by Layne Staley in many of his songs, notably in “Junkhead”, from the 1992 album “Dirt”, where he writes:

You can’t understand a user’s mind
But try, with your books and degrees

This quote tells us that Layne feels like he is something to be judged and studied by psychiatrists and doctors because they can’t understand why he would take drugs, which supports the fact that general society looks down on drug users.']]), ('Yeah, I’m going to blackball your name
 Ain’t no way you’ll go without me', [['To “blackball” means to ostracize or exclude someone from social or commercial participation. This line could be interpeted as the drugs being personified and talking to him, telling him how they’re going ruin his life by tarnishing his image and branding him an addict.

The word “blackball” is also similar to “blackmail”, which feeds into the second line where he is told that he cannot go on without them, and is a slave to drugs due to the power they hold over him.']]), ('I’d like to have more of you in my veins', [['Most likely a heroin or cocaine reference.']])]

[Outro: Jerry Cantrell & Jerry Cantrell & Layne Staley]

Something's gotta turn out rightYou might also like9Embed
annotation:
[('I can’t let go
 Threadbare tapestry unwinding slow', [['He can’t let go of his lover even though their love is falling apart, hence an unwinding tapestry, the word threadbare is used, giving the idea of a ramshackle and thrown together appearance. Their relationship was held together by painter’s tape and school glue. And now it’s broken.']]), ('Show your belly like you want me to', [['While there are many reasons an animal might expose its belly, the metaphor here is about vulnerability. Just like a wolf might show its vulnerable belly to the alpha as a gesture of accepting his authority; relationships require gestures of vulnerability so that trust can grow. This could entail telling each other about one’s weaknesses, fears and anxieties; as opposed to maintaining an appearance of strength at all times.

Jerry makes the point that if she expects him to be open and vulnerable around her; she should be willing to do the same.']]), ('As of now I bet you got me wrong
 So unsure you run from something strong', [['In the linear notes of the 1999 Music Bank box set collection, Jerry Cantrell said on the song:

That’s about girl I was dating in between one of the times I broke up with my true love. A lot of times you’ll tell someone how you don’t want to be in a relationship and why, and what kind of person you are, and they hear all that but think that they can change you. That’s what the song’s about, getting me wrong and the different ways that men and women see each other.

If we dissect the lyrics of the song, we can surmise that it’s Cantrell speaking to his girlfriend at the time, saying how she has the wrong idea about the premise of their relationship. He (might) be with her as a ‘rebound’, or someone you date after a long term relationship in order to get over your feelings for the person you just broke up with.

Another possible, but less likely, meaning could be that his current lady-friend thinks that she is just a rebound, whereas Cantrell is honestly trying to show that actually cares about her. That way, the line “so unsure, you run from something strong” could mean she’s turning away from Cantrell, who is ready to commit to solely her, because she isn’t able to tell if she’s being objectified or not.']])]

title: Them Bones (2022 Remaster)
lyrics:
The Vampire, His Kith And Kin - Chapter 3 LyricsCHAPTER III

THE TRAITS AND PRACTICE OF VAMPIRISM

IT was generally supposed that all suicides might after death become vampires; and this was easily extended to those who met with any violent or sudden death. Mr. Lawson tells us that there persists a tradition in Maina, where the Vendetta is still maintained, that a man whose murder has not been avenged is liable to become a vrykolakas.[1] The Mainotes who derive their name from the place Maina, near Cape Taenaron (Matapan), even yet preserve many of the customs and characteristics of their ancestors, and historically are known to be of a more pure Greek descent than the inhabitants of any other district. Indeed, the peninsula which thrusts into the sea the headland of Taenaron has both social and religious customs of its own. The population is distributed into small villages, while here and there a white fortress will denote the residence of a chief. A traveller writing in 1858, remarks: "The Maina country is wild and beautiful, singularly well cultivated, considering the difficulties to be surmounted, and producing crops that put to shade the rich plains of Argos and Arcadia; whilst the interesting mountain people exercise the highland virtues of hospitality and independance to an extent unknown in the low countries." It has been said that the last traveller who saw Maina while retaining some remains of its primitive cateran glories was Lord Carnarvon, who in 1839 explored the Morea and has left us an extraordinarily interesting account of his journey.

The population of this district continued the worship of the Pagan deities for full five hundred years after the rest of the Roman Empire had embraced Christianity, and they were not finally converted until the reign of the vigorous Emperor Basil I, 867-886. Gibbon described them as "a domestic and perhaps original race, who, in some degree, might derive their blood from the much-injured Helotes."[2] And even yet

p. 141

they boast of their descent from the ancient Spartans, whilst the histories of Leonidas and Lycurgus, who figure partly as saints and partly as gallant brigands, are still retold round the winter fireside. The whole district, including Kaka Voulia (the Land of Evil Counsel), is formed by the hummocks and escarpments of Mount Taygetos, and, with the exception of a long strip of coast line, which the Venetians called Bassa Maina, it is steep and hilly and for the most part barren. The conquest of the Morea was completed by Mahomet II in 1456-1460, but Maina could never be thoroughly subdued, and its inhabitants remained as entirely independent as were the Highlanders before Culloden.
As has been remarked, ancient traditions still persevere, and among these customs not the least obstinate is the Vendetta. A man who has been murdered is unable to rest in his grave until he has been avenged. Accordingly he issues forth as a vampire, thirsting for the blood of his enemy. In order to bring about his physical dissolution and to secure his repose it is necessary for the next of kin to slay the murderer, or at least some near relative of the murderer. Unless this is done the man upon whom the duty of avenging blood devolves is banned by the curse of the dead, and if so be that he is himself cut off before he can satify the desires of the deceased, the curse will yet cling to him even in death, and he too must become a vampire. It should be remarked that this view of blood-guilt is found in the Attic dramatists, and is in fact the mainspring of the whole story of Orestes. In the tragedy of this name by Euripides, Tyndareus, the father of Clytemnestra, remonstrates very reasonably, and indeed unanswerably with Orestes. But the hero replies and argues that if he has not avenged his father

Had not his hate's Erinyes haunted me?[3]

Again in the Choephoroe of Aeschylus Orestes pursues the same idea saying that unless he avenges his father, a stern duty which has devolved upon him, lie will be punished in turn by the avengers of his father's wrongs. It may be remarked that in Maina to-day no recourse must be had to law for such cases, nor must the injured person satisfy himself by calling upon the aid of the police. To do this were incredibly base, the subterfuge of a recreant and a craven. Even if it be a life's whole work a man is expected, either secretly

p. 142

or by an open attack, to slay the murderer of his relative, and he is highly applauded when he has accomplished this pious deed. It must be appreciated that he is regarded as herein directed and inspired by the dead man who returns from his grave as a vampire craving for blood. Even if no other motive or incentive prevailed, in spite of natural shrinking and may be even cowardice, a man would undoubtedly prefer to shed blood for blood, especially when this might be done in secrecy or by craft, rather than run the terrible risk of himself becoming a vampire, finding no rest in the grave, but returning to haunt and persecute even those who were most dear to him, an unclean thing accursed. of God, a foul goblin of dread most hateful to man.

So great is the horror which the act of suicide, although considered admirable in the decadence of Greece and Rome, inspires in every man of sane mind that it, is not at all surprising it should be deemed that the unfortunate wretches who have destroyed themselves become vampires after death. According to the Zoroastrian creed, suicide is a most fearful crime, and is classed among the marg-arzan, the abominable offences. Aristotle in his Ethics, V, xv, terms suicide a sin against the State, and as Cicero tells us Pythagoras forbade men to depart from their guard or sentry-go in life without an order from their commanding-officer, who is God. "Uetatque Pythagoras iniussu imperatoris, id est, dei, de praesidio et statione uitae decedere." (De Senectute, XX, 73). The highest pagan argument against suicide will be found in Plato's Phaedo (61E-62E), but it is drowned in the mighty voice of the great Saint of Hippo, which peals in no unwavering tones down the centuries: "For if it be not lawful for a private man to kill any man, however guilty, unless the law have granted a special allowance for it, theft surely whosoever kills himself is guilty of homicide: and so much the more guilty doth that killing of himself make himself, by how much the more guiltless he was in that cause for which he killed himself. For if the act of Judas be worthily detested, and yet the Truth saith, that by hanging of himself, he did rather augment than expiate the guilt of his wicked treachery, because his despair of God's mercy in his damnable repentance, left no place in his soul for saving repentance; how much more ought he to

p. 143

forbear from being cause of his own death, that hath no guilt in him worthy of such a punishment as death; for Judas in hanging himself, hanged but a wicked man and died guilty, not only of Christ's death, but of his own also; adding the wickedness of being his own death, to that other wickedness of his, for which he died." (De Ciuitate Dei, I, xvii.)

It may be well very briefly to present the teaching of the Church concerning positive and direct suicide. If done without God's permission this always constitutes a grave injustice towards Him. To destroy a thing is in effect to dispose of it as an absolute master and to act with regard to it as one who has full and independent dominion over it. But God has reserved to Himself dominion over life. Man cannot create life, and he does not possess this full and absolute right over his own life. Consequently suicide must be reckoned as an attempt against the dominion and right of ownership of the Author of life. To this injustice is super-added a serious offence against the charity owed by man to himself, since by self-murder he deprives himself of the greatest good in his possession. Moreover this sin may be aggravated by other circumstances, such as an offence against conjugal, paternal, or filial duty; an offence against justice or charity; if by taking his own life a man eludes existing obligations of justice or acts of charity which he could and should perform. That suicide is unlawful is the general teaching of Holy Scripture which condemns the act as a most terrible crime, and to arouse the horror of all against Holy Church denies the suicide the rites of Christian burial. Again, suicide is directly opposed to the most natural and powerful tendency of all created things, and especially of intelligent man, the preservation of life. Indeed very large numbers of physicians, moralists, and jurists lay it down as a general rule that suicide is always due to dementia, so great is the horror which this atrocious deed inspires in every man of sane mind. As a generalization this may be admitted to be true, for it is impossible to think that those who have the calm and right use of their reason should deliberately destroy themselves, and the conditions which are necessary to incur the full culpability of an act can only in exceptional instances be conceived of as being present in the case of a suicide. Sabetti inquires: "Quaenam ad peccatum mortale

p. 144

requirantur?" And his answer is given as follows: "Tria necessario requiruntur, scilicet materia grauis uel in se, uel ob circumstantias; aduertentia plena ad malitiam grauem actus; consensus plenus uoluntatis in præuaricationem. Itaque,

Requiritur 1°. materia grauis, secus non posset haberi lex obligans sub graui.

Requiritur 2°. plena aduertentia mentis, secus non habebitur plena deliberatio.
Requiritur 3°. plenus consensus uoluntatis, quia nisi peccator cum pleno consensu plenaque deliberatione obiectum peccati Deo præferat, et sic finem suum ultimum in creatura constituat, nequit dici a Deo totaliter recedere. Insuper a bonitate diuina prorsus alienum est, hominem æternæ damnationi addicere siue propter transgressionem leuem siue propter actum non perfecte liberum et uoluntarium.--Cf. S. Alphons, nn. 5, 6 et 53."[5]

The Christian Middle Ages were free from the terrible tendency of suicide, but with the loss of Faith it re-appeared, and Masaryk in his study Der Selbstmord als sociale Massenerscheinung der modernen Civilisation (Vienna, 1881), considered it to be the special evil of these later days. Sad to relate self-destruction has fearfully increased since the Great War, but it may perhaps be mitigatingly advanced that the reason of the world tottered almost to eternal delirium during the chaos and welter of blood, and the balance is not recovered yet.

It is true that among certain nations there appears to be an indifference to human life, nay, a contempt of death itself, which often takes the most extravagant and the most outrageous forms. The Goths, the heathen Vandals, and Norse savages not only approved but sought suicide and violent death. It is, of course, only among the utterly benighted that it is possible for such abominable ideas to obtain. For example, there existed among a tribe of robbers in Southern India customs of the utmost ferocity. Such practices as the following certainly prevailed during the eighteenth century, but they have no doubt, long since been happily suppressed. If two persons had quarrelled, sometimes for the most trifling reasons, a man would kill himself merely in order to be revenged on his adversary. He believed that

p. 145

his ghost would be able to return and harry the surviver , or at least that some dire retribution must fall on the head of his enemy who drove him to such extreme measures.[6] Again, custom required that if a man committed suicide, letting it be known that it was on this account, the person with whom he had had the difference that led to this abominable act must immediately follow his example.[7]

Lord Avebury's statement:[8] "It is said that in China, if a rich man is condemned to death, he can sometimes purchase a willing substitute at a very small expense," has been traversed and Professor Parker would not commit himself any further than by saying: "It is popularly stated that substitutes can be bought for Taels fifty, and most certainly this statement is more than true, so far as the price of human life is concerned; but it is quite another question whether the gaolers and judges can always be bribed."[9] Dr. W. T. A. Barber, who had been a missionary in China, relates that he had known very large numbers of persons who committed suicide out of spite against some one else, "the idea being, first, the trouble given by minions of the law to the survivor; second that the dead would gain a vantage ground by becoming a ghost, and thus able to plague his enemy in the flesh."[10]

It is not surprising to learn that in ancient times, before the advent of Christianity, among such savage people as the Celts and the Thracians suicide was not only common but treated with the most appalling lightness and even flippancy. Thus Athenæus, speaking of the banquets of the Thracians, quotes from Seleueus as follows: "And Seleueus says, 'that some of the Thracians at their drinking parties play the game of hanging; and fix a round noose to some high place, exactly beneath which they place a stone which is easily turned round when any one stands upon it; and then they cast lots, and he who draws the lot, holding a sickle in his hand, stands upon the stone, and puts his neck into the halter; and then another person comes and raises the stone, and the man who is suspended, when the stone moves from under him, if he is not quick enough in cutting the rope with his sickle, is killed and the rest laugh, thinking his death good sport.'"[11]

Upon the authority of the famous Stoic philosopher, Posidonius, Athenæus tells us of similar brutalities which took place among the Celts. He writes: "But Posidonius,[12] in the

p. 146

third, and also in the twentieth book of his Histories, says 'The Celtæ sometimes have single combats at their entertainments. For being collected in arms, they go through the exercise, and make feints at, and sometimes they even go so far as to wound one another. And being irritated by this, if the bystanders do not stop them, they will proceed even to kill one another. But in olden times,' he continues, 'there was a custom that a hind quarter of pork was put on the table, and the bravest man took it; and if any one else laid claim to it, then the two rose up to fight, till one of them was slain. And other men in the theatre having received some silver or gold money, and some even for a number of earthen vessels full of wine, having taken pledges that the gifts promised shall really be given, and having distributed them among their nearest connexions, have laid themselves down on doors with their faces upwards, and then allowed some bystander to cut their throats with a sword.'

"And Euphorion the Chalcidian, in his Historical Memorials, writes as follows: 'But among the Romans it is common for five minæ[13] to be offered to any one who chooses to take it, to allow his head to be cut off with an axe, so that his heirs might receive the reward: and very often many have returned their names as willingly, so that there has been a regular contest between them as to who had the best right to be beaten to death.'"[14] These atrocious examples serve to show us something of the evil and the corruption of which Christianity cleansed the pagan world, although it is to be feared that the battle is not yet won, since it is a notorious and deplorable fact that at the hour of such a crisis as the Great War the respect due to human life became cheapened in men's eyes, with the consequence that murder and deeds of violence once more broke out in every direction showing that savage instincts were dominated indeed, but in many cases not wholly eradicated. It does not require a keen perception to see the direct agency of the devil here, and these atrocities which bred so callous and cruel a spirit are by no means altogether unconnected with the recrudescence of necromancy and black magic which foul arts once more grew green and were almost openly pursued on every side.

The belief that a man has not complete dominion over his own life and that it is unlawful for him to take it is certainly a

p. 147
feeling naturally implanted in the human breast, and it was only when nations were entirely barbarian or had became decadent and corrupt that the notion of suicide was held up as noble and even heroic. Whatever certain among the later Greeks may have practised and taught, in earlier days, as we have seen, the act of suicide was regarded as a dark and presumptuous deed. They truly felt that there was in it something of ἀσέβεια,[15] something of that ὕβρις which so surely stirred the wrath of heaven and inevitably called down righteous vengeance. Indeed the evil and malice of suicide did not end with death but continued beyond the grave. The umbra of a man who had slain himself was dreaded and feared. So in ancient Athens it was the custom to cut off the hand of a suicide and to cremate it or at least to bury it far from his body, the object of such mutilation being to prevent his ghost from attacking the living.[16]

Similar beliefs exist among native African tribes. Thus the Wajagga of East Africa dread the spectres of suicides. When a man has hanged himself a certain complicated ceremonial becomes imperative. They take the rope from his neck and suspend a goat in the noose, after which the animal is swiftly slain. The idea seems that hereby the phantom will be in some way appeased, and he will not be so likely to tempt human beings to follow his evil example.[17]
